revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict = 1964 T-39 shootdown incident |partof = the [[Cold War]] |image = North American T-39A Sabre Liner USAF.jpg |image_size = 300px |alt=A white-and blue twin-engined training jet |caption = A T-39 Sabreliner of the U.S. Air Force |date = 28 January 1964 |place = [[Vogelsberg, Thuringia|Vogelsberg]], [[East Germany]] |map_type =East Germany |coordinates = {{coord|51.119322|11.23345|type:event|display=inline}} |map_size =300px |map_caption = |map_label = |territory = |result = One aircraft shot down |combatant1 = {{flagu|United States}} |combatant2 = {{flagu|Soviet Union|1955}} |casualties1 = 3 [[USAF]] officers killed |casualties2 = None }}
The '''1964 T-39 shootdown incident''' occurred on 28 January 1964, when an unarmed [[United States Air Force]] [[North American Sabreliner|T-39 Sabreliner]] on a training mission was shot down over [[Erfurt]], [[East Germany]] by a [[Soviet Air Force|Soviet]] [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-19]] fighter aircraft.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710195808/http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=573 |title=Factsheets : North American T-39A Sabreliner |publisher=Nationalmuseum.af.mil |accessdate=13 April 2010}}</ref><ref name=T39>{{cite web|url=http://www.western-allies-berlin.com/units/military-liaison-mission/usmlm/detail/t-39-crash |title=T-39 Aircraft Incident |publisher=Western-allies-berlin.com |date=28 January 1964 |accessdate=13 April 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19640128-0 Aviation Safety Network] Retrieved on 27 October 2011</ref> The occupants of the aircraft were Lieutenant Colonel Gerald K. Hannaford, Captain Donald Grant Millard and Captain John F. Lorraine. All three died,<ref name=time>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,870650,00.html|title=Cold War: Cold Blooded Murder|work=Time|date=7 February 1964|accessdate=17 April 2010}}</ref> becoming some of the few US confirmed direct casualties of the [[Cold War (1962–1979)|Cold War]] in Europe.
== Background == {{Main|Cold War}} Following the cessation of hostilities at the end of World War II, a situation which came to be known as the [[Cold War]] developed between the United States, Canada, and [[NATO|Western European nations]] on one side, and the [[Warsaw Pact|Soviet bloc]] on the other.<ref>{{harvnb|Blainey|2005|pp=274–277}}</ref> Tensions between the United States and [[Soviet Union]] were most felt in the regions bordering the [[Iron Curtain]], notably [[West Germany]] and [[East Germany]], and during this time relations between the two superpowers were characterized by hostile attitudes, spying, and numerous incidents resulting in loss of life and equipment. One of the most famous of these is the [[1960 U-2 incident|shooting down]] of a [[Lockheed U-2]] spy plane, piloted by [[Francis Gary Powers]], over the Soviet Union in May 1960.<ref>{{harvnb|Blainey|2005|pp=344–345}}</ref>
== Event == On 28 January 1964, an unarmed USAF [[North American Sabreliner|North American T-39A Sabreliner]] twin engine jet trainer, ''62-4448'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19640128-0 |title=ASN Aircraft accident North American CT-39A Sabreliner 62-4448 Vogelsberg village, Thüringen |publisher=Aviation-safety.net |date= |accessdate=28 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joebaugher.com/usaf_serials/1962.html |title=1962 USAF Serial Numbers |publisher=Joebaugher.com |date= |accessdate=28 January 2014}}</ref> of the 7101st Air Base Wing, departed [[Wiesbaden]], West Germany, at 14:10 on a routine three-hour training flight. On board the trainer were three men, Captain John F. Lorraine and students Lieutenant Colonel Gerald K. Hannaford and Captain Donald G. Millard. Lorraine was the qualified instructor, while Hannaford and Millard, both pilots with experience on other types, were being trained in order to qualify on the T-39.<ref name=time />
The flight proceeded uneventfully until, 47 minutes after takeoff, [[radar]] at two U.S. air defense stations noticed that the trainer was heading toward East Germany at {{convert|500|mph}}.<ref name=time /> Hoping to divert the T-39 back on course, each station began hailing the plane on Air Force frequencies and a Soviet-monitored international distress band. Repeated calls to the T-39 went unanswered. It appeared that the T-39's radio systems malfunctioned and the crew were unable to respond.<ref name=time />
The T-39 crossed the border into East Germany. Within five minutes, two blips appeared near the American jet. For 11 minutes, radar blips indicated the three planes were moving eastward, then two blips suddenly veered west and the third blip disappeared. American personnel monitoring the T-39's flight could not determine what had happened, although it was later reported that residents in [[Vogelsberg, Thuringia|Vogelsberg]], {{convert|50|mi|km|sp=us}} from the border, had heard machine-gun and cannon fire and had witnessed the plane crash.<ref name=time /> The incident is believed to have occurred at 15:14 hours.<ref name=T39 />
At 17:00 hours on 28 January the United States [[Military Liaison Missions|Military Liaison Mission]] (USMLM), in Berlin, received a warning to stand by for possible search and rescue of American airmen.<ref name=T39 /> By 18:00 hours, a search team left Berlin for the Erfurt area of East Germany. At 19:15 hours, the chief of the USMLM met with his Soviet counterpart to request help in finding the plane and rescuing survivors (per the Huebner–Malinin Agreement).<ref name=T39 />
At 20:00 hours, a second search team left Berlin. About this same time, the first team arrived at the crash site, {{convert|20|km|mi|sp=us}} north of Erfurt. The first team received a report from an East German civilian that a U.S. plane had crashed and burned, and that the crew was dead.<ref name=T39 /> Throughout the night, the American teams tried to approach the aircraft and were repeatedly sent away by the armed Soviet forces on site.<ref name=T39 /> These forces denied that any aircraft had crashed, and two American search teams were detained briefly before being released at 14:00 hours on 29 January.<ref name=T39 />
== Aftermath == By 29 January, the [[United States State Department]] charged that the Soviet Union shot down an unarmed plane and caused the needless deaths of three officers. Secretary of State [[Dean Rusk]] called the action a "shocking and senseless act."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19640130&id=d50RAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BekDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6479,5227671|title=Red Attack on U.S. Jet: Three Americans Killed in Unarmed Trainer Crash|work=The Spokesman Review|date=30 January 1964|accessdate=17 April 2010}}</ref> Through the Soviet press agency, [[Telegraph Agency of the Soviet Union|Tass]], Moscow claimed that the plane had intruded over East German territory and failed to react to signals, and then a warning shot. The Soviets said they were compelled to take the measure that brought down the U.S. plane.<ref name=time />
On 30 January, the Soviets agreed to allow US personnel access to the crash site.<ref name=T39 /> This occurred the following day and later the bodies of all three servicemen were returned to the United States through [[Joint Base Andrews Naval Air Facility|Andrews Air Force Base]] in Maryland. General [[Curtis E. LeMay]] met the plane and participated in an honors ceremony.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_RweAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Y34EAAAAIBAJ&pg=3092,2204853&dq=shot+down+millard|title=US to Fly Bodies of Airmen Home|work=The Milwaukee Journal|date= 5 February 1964|accessdate=17 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19640129&id=DRUOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5HwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4775,4839495 |title=Soviets Admit Downing U.S. Plane |work=St. Petersburg Times |date=29 January 1964 |accessdate=17 April 2010 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The aircraft wreckage was also recovered and was taken to Berlin, arriving there on 1 February 1964.<ref name=T39 /> [[File:Vogelsberg Fliegerdenkmal 2.JPG|thumb|Memorial at the crash site near Vogelsberg]]
== Memorial == Residents from the nearby town of [[Vogelsberg, Thuringia|Vogelsberg]] in Thuringia erected a memorial to the three downed pilots, in 1998, once the "[[Iron Curtain]]" had been lifted.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.usafe.af.mil/News/Article-Display/Article/749105/german-village-remembers-downed-american-pilots/|title=German village remembers downed American pilots|work=U.S. Air Forces in Europe & Air Forces Africa|access-date=2017-06-18|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmlm.org/home/coldwar/shootdowns/1964t39shootdown.htm|title=A Cold Night in Erfurt|publisher=usmlm.org|accessdate=17 April 2010}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Cold War|United States Air Force}} * [[1961 F-84 Thunderstreak incident]]
== References == ;Notes {{reflist|2}} ;References {{refbegin}} * {{cite book|last=Blainey|first=Geoffrey|title=A Short History of the 20th century|year=2005|publisher=Viking|location=Camberwell, Victoria|isbn=0-670-04273-0|ref=harv}} {{refend}}
== Further reading == {{Commons category|Shot-down aviators}} {{refbegin}} * Olsen, Arthur J., "U.S. Jet Lost in East Germany; It May Have Been Shot Down", ''[[The New York Times]]'', 28 January 1964. * Raymond, Jack, "U.S. Says Soviet Shot Down Jet", ''[[The New York Times]]'', 29 January 1964. {{refend}}
{{coord|51|07|09.56|N|11|14|00.42|E|type:event|display=title}}

page.title: 2018 Case of babies born without arms in France

revision.text:
In October 2018, doctors in France demanded an investigation into why thirteen babies in three rural areas had been born without hands, forearms or arms in three rural areas, between 2007 and 2017.<ref>https://www.reuters.com/article/us-france-health-babies/france-investigates-reports-of-babies-born-without-arms-in-rural-areas-idUSKCN1N51MV</ref><ref name="Guardian">{{cite news |last1=Willsher |first1=Kim |title=French doctors fail to solve mystery of babies with missing limbs |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/oct/08/france-doctors-fail-solve-mystery-babies-missing-limbs |accessdate=15 November 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=8 October 2018}}</ref> The public health authority initially stated that the incidents were not significantly higher than the national average, and they would not investigate further.<ref name="Guardian"/> However, after additional cases were reported, also in rural areas, health minister [[Agnès Buzyn]] launched a nationwide investigation into the causes in November 2018.<ref name="ABC">{{cite news |title=France opens probe on babies born without hands or arms |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-11-01/french-babies-born-with-no-hands-arms-probe-launched/10453596 |accessdate=15 November 2018 |work=ABC News |agency=Reuters |date=1 November 2018 |location=Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=French Ain babies: Missing limb births prompt national inquiry |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-46043564 |accessdate=15 November 2018 |work=BBC News |date=31 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Senthilingam |first1=Meera |title=France launches nationwide investigation after babies born with missing or malformed limbs |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/11/01/health/france-babies-missing-limbs-investigation-intl/index.html |accessdate=15 November 2018 |work=CNN |date=1 November 2018}}</ref>
[[Amelia (birth defect)|Amelia]] (lack of one of more limbs) and [[meromelia]] (partial absence of one or more limbs) can have multiple causes, including chromosomal disorders, infection, or exposure to toxic substances at a critical time in the development of the embryo, between the 6th and 8th week, when the arms and legs appear.<ref name="ABC"/><ref>https://navva.org/belgium/health/7-factors-that-can-explain-these-deformities/</ref>.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Health disasters]] [[Category:Health disasters in France]] [[Category:2018 health disasters]]

revision.text:
The '''[[Australian and New Zealand Army Corps|ANZAC]] Field of Remembrance''' is an annual event held at [[St. Andrew's Cathedral, Sydney]],<ref name="NLAWWGNSW">[http://nla.gov.au/nla.party-764067 War Widows' Guild of Australia NSW Limited (1946–), Trove, National Library of Australia]</ref> which is hosted by the War Widows' Guild of Australia NSW Ltd. The event involves the planting of wooden crosses in remembrance of those who have died due to their involvement in war.<ref name="DPC">[http://www.dpc.nsw.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0019/44380/090422_War_Widows_Guild.pdf Department of Premier and Cabinet NSW (22 April 2009), Minister attends War Widows’ Guild ANZAC Service] News Release.</ref> [[File:Field of Remembrance Young Family 2009.JPG|thumb|A young family look at the crosses planted in the ANZAC Field of Remembrance, Sydney, April 2009]]
== History == The first Field of Remembrance in Sydney was held in 1952.<ref name="DPC" /> It was an idea that originated from the late Mrs C J Pope, widow of Rear Admiral Pope, after she had visited London and been impressed by the [[Field of Remembrance]] held each year in an old churchyard near [[Westminster Abbey]].<ref name="NLAWWGNSW" /> In 1972 the Attorney-General granted the War Widows’ Guild of Australia NSW Ltd permission to use the word 'ANZAC' in the title, and the Field has been known since then as the ANZAC Field of Remembrance and continues to the present day.<ref name="BurgeP70">Burge, Roslyn (2008), ''No Peacetime Cinderellas: A History of the War Widows’ Guild of Australia in New South Wales 1946–2006'', Australia: War Widows’ Guild of Australia NSW Ltd, {{ISBN|9780646477374}} (hbk.) p. 70</ref>
== The Ceremony == A non-denominational service is held prior to [[Anzac Day]] at St Andrew’s Cathedral, Sydney, with a lesson read by the [[Governor of New South Wales]].<ref name="WWGWebsiteFoR">[http://www.warwidowsnsw.com.au/About_the_Guild/ANZAC_Field_of_Rememberance.htm War Widows Guild of Australia NSW Website]</ref> The service is followed by the Dedication of the Field and the planting of the official crosses. The first cross is planted by the Governor in memory of [[The Unknown Warrior]], followed by crosses planted on behalf of the three armed forces: Navy, Army and Air Force; the citizens of Sydney; New Zealanders and their armed forces; veterans; and war widows. The Field was originally laid out on the lawn adjoining the Cathedral near Bathurst Street. Since 2016 the Field has been in Hyde Park on the Corner of Park Street and Elizabeth Street close to the ANZAC Memorial. The crosses are planted in a set of flower boxes that are periodically used to decorate the [[City of Sydney]].<ref name="BurgeP73">Burge, Roslyn (2008), ''No Peacetime Cinderellas: A History of the War Widows’ Guild of Australia in New South Wales 1946–2006'', Australia: War Widows’ Guild of Australia NSW Ltd, {{ISBN|9780646477374}} (hbk.) p. 73</ref>
== The Crosses == The small wooden crosses are colour-coded to represent the different armed forces. A sprig of [[rosemary]] is attached to each cross which represents a loved one gone but remembered. They are each personalised with hand written names or small messages.<ref name="BurgeP73" /> After the Field of Remembrance is closed, the crosses are cremated and scattered on the graves of veterans in a memorial garden.<ref>Burge, Roslyn (2008), ''No Peacetime Cinderellas: A History of the War Widows’ Guild of Australia in New South Wales 1946–2006'', Australia: War Widows’ Guild of Australia NSW Ltd, {{ISBN|9780646477374}} (hbk.) p. 71</ref>
== Duration == The Field of Remembrance is open for widows and members of the public to place crosses in personal remembrance, from the day of the commemoration service until the late afternoon on Anzac Day.<ref name="WWGWebsiteFoR" />
== Milestone == The Guild held its 60th ANZAC Field of Remembrance on 19 April 2011.<ref>[http://www.warwidowsnsw.com.au/pdfs/Digest_Mar_2011.pdf War Widows’ Guild of Australia NSW Limited, “Our President’s Message”, Guild Digest, March 2011] p. 5, ISSN 1449-3691</ref> At this service, war widows from major and recent conflicts laid sprays of flowers on the Chancel steps of the Cathedral. The Governor of New South Wales, Her Excellency Professor Marie Bashir AC CVO unveiled a plaque to recognise this milestone of 60 years.
== Other Fields of Remembrance == Following the establishment of the Sydney Field of Remembrance, the War Widows’ Guild has also held Fields of Remembrance in Albury, Newcastle, The Entrance and Tamworth.<ref>Burge, Roslyn (2008), ''No Peacetime Cinderellas: A History of the War Widows’ Guild of Australia in New South Wales 1946–2006'', Australia: War Widows’ Guild of Australia NSW Ltd, {{ISBN|9780646477374}} (hbk.) pp. 75–76</ref> The War Widows’ Guild in the Australian Capital Territory<ref>[http://www.act.raafa.org.au/news/newsletter-Jun%2009.pdf RAAF Association (ACT Division) (June 2009), Field of Remembrance Ceremony] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110221121118/http://www.act.raafa.org.au/news/newsletter-Jun%2009.pdf |date=February 21, 2011 }} Newsletter</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gg.gov.au/speech.php/view/id/210/title/war-widows-guild-of-australia-act-13th-field-of-remembrance |title=His Excellency Major General Michael Jeffery AC CVO MC, Speech, 20 April 2007, Canberra |access-date=2011-04-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110328045341/http://www.gg.gov.au/speech.php/view/id/210/title/war-widows-guild-of-australia-act-13th-field-of-remembrance |archive-date=2011-03-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> and Tasmania<ref>[http://www.govhouse.tas.gov.au/sites/default/files/annual-reports/Gov-House-Annual-Report-2009-2010.pdf Office of the Governor of Tasmania (2009–2010), The Year in Review] Annual Report</ref> also hold Fields of Remembrance.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.warwidowsnsw.com.au/ War Widows Guild of Australia NSW]

({{Age in years, months, weeks and days|month1=10|day1=1|year1=2013|month2=12|day2=1|year2=2013}}) |place = [[Aleppo Governorate]], [[Syria]] |coordinates = |map_type = |map_relief = |latitude = |longitude = |map_size = |map_marksize = |map_caption = |map_label = |result = Syrian Army victory |territory = * Syrian Army captures Khanasir, Al-Safira, Tell Aran, Tell Hassel, Base 80 and 20 smaller villages and towns and reopens the highway to Aleppo |combatant1 = {{flagicon|Syria|1932}} [[Free Syrian Army]]
{{flagicon image|Flag of the Al-Nusra Front.svg}} [[Al-Nusra Front]]

{{flagicon|Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant}} [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] |combatant2 = {{flagicon|Syria}} '''[[Syrian Arab Republic]]''' * {{flagicon image|Syrian Armed Forces Flag.svg}} [[Syrian Armed Forces]]{{cite web|author= Belga |url=http://www.7sur7.be/7s7/fr/16921/Syrie/article/detail/1716239/2013/10/03/L-armee-reprend-une-localite-cle-pour-Alep.dhtml |title=L'armée reprend une localité clé pour Alep |publisher=7SUR7.be |date=3 October 2013 |accessdate=18 November 2013}}[http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/84493/World/Region/Syria-air-force-strikes-rebels-near-Damascus,-Alep.aspx Syria air force strikes rebels near Damascus, Aleppo: NGO] [[Al Ahram]] (AFP), 22 October 2013 * {{flagicon image|InfoboxNDF.png}} [[National Defense Force (Syria)|National Defense Force]] {{flagicon image|InfoboxHez.PNG}} [[Hezbollah]]{{cite news |url=http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/7abf270041c4038e9494bd1c2eddf908/Syria-rebels-recapture-army-base-near-Aleppo-airport-20130911 |title=Syria rebels recapture army base near Aleppo airport |work=Reuters |publisher=[[South African Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=9 November 2013 |accessdate=18 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112155643/http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/7abf270041c4038e9494bd1c2eddf908/Syria-rebels-recapture-army-base-near-Aleppo-airport-20130911 |archivedate=12 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }} |commander1 =[[Abdul Jabbar al-Oqaidi]]
(Aleppo province FSA commander) (resigned){{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2013/Nov-04/236755-leading-fsa-commander-quits-lashes-out-at-lack-of-support.ashx#axzz2lqpFZAqC |title=Leading FSA commander quits, lashes out at lack of support |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date=4 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}}
[[Abdul Qader Saleh]]{{KIA}}
(Al-Tawhid Brigade commander)[http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/86539/World/Region/Syria-air-strike-hits-Islamist-brigade-leadership.aspx Syria air strike hits Islamist brigade leadership] [[Al Ahram]] (AFP), 15 November 2013[https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/18/us-syria-crisis-commander-idUSBRE9AH03H20131118 Top Syrian rebel commander dies from wounds] (Reuters), 18 November 2013{{Clear}}[[Abou al-Tayyeb]]{{KIA}}
(Al-Tawhid Brigade intelligence chief){{cite news|url=http://www.lorientlejour.com/article/842077/syrie-cinq-commandants-rebelles-tues-dans-des-combats-et-des-raids.html |title=Syrie : cinq commandants rebelles tués dans des combats et des raids |publisher=[[L'Orient-Le Jour]] |date= |accessdate=18 November 2013}} |commander2 = Brig. Gen. [[Suheil Al Hassan]]{{cite web |author=Edward Dark Columnist |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/02/barrel-bombing-syria-aleppo-rebels-regime-war.html# |title=Barrel bombings cause mass evacuation in east Aleppo |publisher=Al-monitor.com |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024205148/http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/02/barrel-bombing-syria-aleppo-rebels-regime-war.html |archive-date=24 October 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}
Maj. Gen. [[Mahmoud Ramadan (syrian military officer)|Mahmoud Ramadan]] (35th Regiment) |units1 = {{flagicon|Syria|1932}} [[Free Syrian Army]]: * [[Al-Tawhid Brigade]] * Jaysh Mohammad Brigade{{cite web|url=http://www.pukmedia.com/EN/EN_Direje.aspx?Jimare=15762 |title=ISIS and al-Nusra reportedly lose their final presence in Reef Ras al-A’in: al-Hasaka |publisher=Pukmedia.com |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014}} * [[Harakat Nour al-Din al-Zenki]] |units2 = {{flagicon image|Flag of the Syrian Arab Army.svg}} [[Syrian Army]]: *3rd Army Corps (Aleppo) *[[File:Syrian commando.png|20px]] [[15th Special Forces Division]]: ** 35th Special Forces Regiment ** 127th Special Forces Regiment ** 403rd Armored Regiment |strength1 = Unknown |strength2 = 7,000 soldiers |casualties1 = 125+ killed{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe?fref=ts |title=Syrian Observatory for Human Rights |publisher=Facebook |date= |accessdate=18 November 2013}} |casualties2 = 105+ killed |casualties3 = 97+ civilians killed{{cite web|author=|url=http://supportkurds.org/news/friday-18-october-2013/ |title=Friday 18 October 2013 |publisher=Supportkurds.org |date=19 October 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} }} {{Campaignbox Battle of Aleppo}} The '''October–December 2013 Aleppo offensive''' or '''Operation Northern Storm'''{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-and-hezbollah-advance-in-southern-and-eastern-aleppo-latest-map-update/|title=Syrian Army and Hezbollah Advance in Southern and Eastern Aleppo – Latest Map Update|author=Leith Fadel|work=Al-Masdar News|date=11 November 2015|accessdate=11 November 2015}} was a campaign during the [[Syrian civil war]] launched by the [[Syrian army]] in the [[Aleppo Governorate]] to reopen a key supply route linking central Syria to the largest city, [[Aleppo]]. The offensive began when the [[Syrian Army]] attacked the strategic town of [[Khanasir]]. == Background == In June 2013, after their strategic [[Battle of al-Qusayr (2013)|capture of al-Qusayr]], government forces launched an offensive called Northern Storm in Aleppo Province aimed at securing supply lines between disparate patches of control in the province. However, increased rebel pressure in [[Homs Governorate|Homs Province]] led the government to abandon the offensive and redeploy its troops there, leaving its supply lines to Aleppo city vulnerable to attack. Later in the summer, rebels capitalised on this strategic weakness. In late July, rebels launched an offensive west of Aleppo city culminating in the capture of several suburbs and [[Khan al-Assal massacre|a massacre of captured government soldiers]], and on 5 August, the long-besieged Menagh Airbase in the north of the province [[Siege of Menagh Air Base|fell to the rebels]]. On 26 August, rebels captured the strategic town of Khanasir, thus cutting the government's last land supply route to the contested city of Aleppo.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/08/2013826124946176888.html|title=Syria rebels take control of strategic town|date=26 August 2013|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=17 October 2013}} Rebels then turned their sights to the government-controlled southern countryside of Aleppo. On 20 September, a coalition of at least ten rebel groups led by [[Ahrar ash-Sham]] and the [[Tawhid Brigade]] launched an offensive called [http://quran.com/100 ''wal-'Adiyat Dabha''] against government positions between the southern edge of the city and the defence factories outside of rebel-held [[Al-Safira]]. In the first six days of the offensive, rebels made significant advances, claiming to have captured at least 25 villages.Names of villages (from The Institute for the Study of War): Kafr Hout, al-Zaraa, Kafr Kar, Banan al-Has, Sarj Far'a, Balouza, Burj 'Azawi, Madrasa village, Im Jaran, Qanatrat, Samaria, Maghriyat al-Shebli, al-Mayan, al-Manatir, Rasm al-Safa, Rasm Humud, Mazraa Ali Hussein, Diyman, Sada’aya, Rasm al-Shih, Mazraa al-Ayoub, Rasm al-Hilwa, Tayeba, Rasm 'Akirish, and al-Sufayrah In response, government forces from [[Aleppo International Airport]] redeployed south to counter the rebel offensive.{{cite web|url=http://iswsyria.blogspot.com/2013/09/offensives-in-aleppo-from-july.html|title=The wal-'Adiyat Dabha Offensive in Southern Aleppo|last=Caris|first=Charlie|author2=Isabel Nassief|date=26 September 2013|publisher=Institute for the Study of War|accessdate=17 October 2013}} == The offensive == === Capture of Khanasir and reopening of the highway === To reopen supply lines to Aleppo city, the government launched a counteroffensive along the so-called "Desert Road" between Aleppo and [[Salamiyah]], dispatching a large convoy from the latter backed with heavy air support. Khanasir, captured by rebels in August, was the first major objective of the Army as it occupies a critical chokepoint on the road. On 1 October, the shelling of Khanasir and fighting between the Army and rebels in the vicinity of the town killed at least 20 rebel fighters. The village of Jub al-Ghaws, near of Khanasir was bombed by helicopters while, according to SOHR, rebel fighters hit a fighter airplane above Khanasir.{{cite web|author=|url=http://supportkurds.org/news/tuesday-1-october-2013/ |title=Tuesday 1 October 2013 |publisher=Supportkurds.org |date=2 October 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} On 2 October, according to SOHR, the Syrian Army progressed in Khanasir, taking control of parts of the city while a large number of rebel positions were hit by the Air Force in the province; al-Atareb, Khan al-A'sal, Kafrnaha and Minnegh military airport.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} On 3 October, the Army took back control of Khanasir, with at least 25 rebel fighters and 18 pro-government militiamen being killed between 1 and 2 October. However, the military had not yet reopened the highway to Aleppo.{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/in-focus/syria/syria-army-retakes-northern-strategic-town-1.1238911 |title=Syria army retakes northern strategic town |publisher=Gulfnews.com |date=3 October 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004064006/http://gulfnews.com/in-focus/syria/syria-army-retakes-northern-strategic-town-1.1238911 |archivedate=4 October 2013 }}{{cite web|author=|url=http://supportkurds.org/news/wednesday-2-october-2013/ |title=Wednesday 2 October 2013 |publisher=Supportkurds.org |date=3 October 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} On 4 October, eight rebels were killed during fighting with the Army in the al-Hmeira mountain, near [[al-Safira]].{{cite web|author=|url=http://supportkurds.org/news/friday-4-october-2013/ |title=Friday 4 October 2013 |publisher=Supportkurds.org |date=5 October 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} On 7 October, the Army managed to reopen the supply route between Aleppo and Khanasir, capturing many surrounding villages{{cite web|url=http://live.aljazeera.com/Event/Syria_Live_Blog/92310948 |title=Syria Live Blog |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=7 October 2013 |accessdate=18 November 2013}} like Rasm Okeiresh, Rasm al-Sheikh, Rasm al-Helou, Rasm Bakrou, al-Wawiyeh, Rasm al-Safa, Barzanieh, Jalagheem, Zarraa, and Kafar Akkad,{{cite web|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/content/syrian-army-ends-opposition-siege-aleppo |title=Syrian Army Ends Opposition Siege on Aleppo |publisher=[[Al Akhbar (Lebanon)]] |date=8 October 2013 |accessdate=18 November 2013}} breaking the siege of Aleppo. According to a governorate source, convoys carrying flour, food supplies, and fuel, went to Aleppo. On 9 October, rebels massacred government soldiers in a village that had only just been captured by the Army.{{cite web|last=Dagher |first=Sam |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303382004579127881524159704 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131011071222/http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702303382004579127881524159704.html |archivedate=11 October 2013 |title=Battles Rage Around Syria Chemical Weapons Sites |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=11 October 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} Elsewhere in the governorate, the Army took the control of other villages; Al-Hamam, Al-Qurbatiy and rebels retreating to Al-Qintein and Al-Bouz.{{cite web|url=http://syrianewsdesk.com/en/2013/10/09/news-regime-forces-control-hama-aleppo-highway |title=Regime forces control the Hama-Aleppo highway |publisher=Syria Newsdesk |date= |accessdate=18 November 2013}} === Capture of al-Safira and Tell Aran === [[File:1alep.png|thumb|left|Situation in Aleppo city during the offensive]] On 10 October, heavy Army shelling and air-strikes of the rebel-held town [[al-Safira]] killed 16-18 civilians. One of the areas that was hit was the town's market. According to one rebel, if opposition forces lost control of al-Safira everything they had accomplished over the previous year in Aleppo would be lost in a matter of days.{{cite web|author=|url=http://supportkurds.org/news/thursday-10-october-2013/ |title=Thursday 10 October 2013 |publisher=Supportkurds.org |date=11 October 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} On 11 October, after clashes, the Army captured the village of Abu Jurayn, in the south of al-Safira.{{cite news|url=http://www.lorientlejour.com/article/837206/syrie-violents-combats-pres-dun-site-chimique-presume.html |title=Syrie: violents combats près d'un site chimique présumé |publisher=L'Orient-Le Jour |date= |accessdate=18 November 2013}} On 17 and 18 October, heavy Army shelling of the rebel-held Kurdish town of [[Tell Aran]] left 21 civilians dead. 11 others were also injured. The town had been captured from Kurdish militants by jihadist rebels earlier in July. By 25 October 76 people had been killed in the shelling of al-Safira since 8 October.{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/world/229227061.html |title=Syrian media say troops ambush, kill 40 rebels near Damascus; Kurdish fighters battle jihadis |publisher=Startribune.com |date=25 October 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} More than 130,000 people fled the city.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.msf.org/article/syria-civilians-forced-flee-al-safira-under-heavy-bombardment |title=Syria: Civilians forced to flee Al Safira under heavy bombardment |publisher=Msf.org |date=25 October 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} On 30 October, the Syrian army entered al-Safira and took over several buildings in the southern part of the city and also advanced on the eastern side the next day.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2013/Nov-01/236453-government-pushes-ahead-with-campaign-in-aleppo-damascus.ashx#axzz2jayn9oCh |title=Government pushes ahead with campaign in Aleppo, Damascus |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014}} By the morning of 1 November, the Army captured the town.{{cite web|url=http://dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2013/Nov-01/236495-syrian-forces-capture-town-near-chemical-weapons-site-activists.ashx#axzz2hs2ziHUm|title=Syrian forces capture town near chemical weapons site: Activists|publisher=Daily Star|date=1 November 2013|accessdate=1 November 2013}} On 2 November, the Army, supported by [[Hezbollah]] officers,{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.net/en/index.php?option=com_news&nid=1081&Itemid=2&task=displaynews#.Up4m58RDufU |title=the Regular forces took hold of the al-A'ziziya village |publisher=Syriahr.net |date=2 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} captured the village of Aziziyeh on the northern outskirts of Safira.{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/warplanes-strike-rebel-area-near-damascus-monitor-143404251.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104234935/http://news.yahoo.com/warplanes-strike-rebel-area-near-damascus-monitor-143404251.html |archivedate=4 November 2013 |title=Air raids on rebel areas near Damascus, Kurds advance: NGO|work=Agence France Presse|publisher=Yahoo! News}} On 4 November, following the loss of Al-Safira, the [[Free Syrian Army]] commander for the province of Aleppo, [[Abdul Jabbar al-Oqaidi]], resigned. On 6 November, the Army captured most of the Kurdish town of [[Tell Aran]] forcing opposition fighters out of it.{{cite news|url=https://now.mmedia.me/lb/en/nowsyrialatestnews/519409-sana-bomb-blast-kills-8-in-central-damascus |title=Deadly bomb rocks central Damascus |publisher=[[NOW News]] |date= |accessdate=18 November 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://live.aljazeera.com/Event/Syria_Live_Blog/95403606 |title=A bomb explosion rocked the heart of the Syrian ca... |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=6 November 2013 |accessdate=18 November 2013}} Some fighting was still occurring in Tell Aran as of 10 November,{{cite web|last=Evans |first=Dominic |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/10/us-syria-crisis-conflict-idUSBRE9A90D620131110 |title=Syrian army retakes northern military base in third day of clashes |publisher=Reuters.com |date=10 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} however, the Army secured the town by the next day. === Battle of Base 80 === On 8 November, before sunrise, the Syrian Army launched an attack against "[[Base 80]]", controlled by the rebels since February 2013, near the Aleppo airport. The Army, backed up by tanks and heavy artillery, unleashed "the heaviest barrage in more than a year" according to residents in Aleppo. A rebel fighter said, "We did not see it coming. The attack came as a real shock to us." According to Al-Jazeera, if the Army captured the base, it would cut the rebel supply routes between Aleppo city and the opposition-controlled town of al-Bab, about 30 kilometers from the Turkish border.{{cite web|url=http://live.aljazeera.com/Event/Syria_Live_Blog/95575090 |title=Syria Live Blog |publisher=Live.aljazeera.com |date=8 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} By morning, the Army took over several areas of "Base 80", leaving them in control of large parts of it. Later in the afternoon, rebel forces, including [[Islamic State of Iraq and Syria|ISIS]], received reinforcements and regrouped, after which they attacked the base. During the fighting, two dozen air and artillery strikes struck rebel positions.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/syria-army-retakes-parts-of-base-by-aleppo-airport-ngo-113110800979_1.html |title=Syria army retakes parts of base by Aleppo airport: NGO |publisher=Business-standard.com |date=8 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/08/us-syria-crisis-aleppo-idUSBRE9A70JN20131108 |title=Syrian army closes in on Aleppo after dawn attack |publisher=Reuters.com |date=8 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} After dark, rebels counter-attacked and by dawn the next day managed to recapture most of the base, with fighting still occurring around it.{{cite web|author=Edward Yeranian |url=http://www.voanews.com/content/syria-rebels-retake-key-base/1786947.html |title=Syria Rebels Retake Key Base |publisher=Voanews.com |date=10 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}}{{cite web |author=Reuters |url=http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/7abf270041c4038e9494bd1c2eddf908/Syria-rebels-recapture-army-base-near-Aleppo-airport-20130911 |title=Syria rebels recapture army base near Aleppo airport |publisher=Sabc.co.za |date=9 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141025071312/http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/7abf270041c4038e9494bd1c2eddf908/Syria-rebels-recapture-army-base-near-Aleppo-airport-20130911 |archivedate=25 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }} During the attack, rebels used GRAD rockets to strike the base.{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/world/article/syria-opposition-wants-pressure-on-damascus-before-agreeing-to-talks |title=Syria opposition wants pressure on Damascus before agreeing to talks |publisher=Themalaymailonline.com |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014}} On 10 November, fighting still continued around "Base 80", with reports of more fighting inside the base itself. During the clashes, rebels targeted two Army armored vehicles, while one rebel tank was destroyed, killing five rebel fighters.{{cite web|author=|url=http://supportkurds.org/news/sunday-10-november-2013/ |title=Sunday 10 November 2013 |publisher=Supportkurds.org |date=11 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pukmedia.com/EN/EN_Direje.aspx?Jimare=15829 |title=Clashes break out between YPG and ISIS |publisher=Pukmedia.com |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014}} By the afternoon, the Army was once again in full control of the base.{{cite web|last=Associated |first=The |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=244302743 |title=Syria Activists: Truce Reached in Blockaded Town |publisher=Wayback.archive.org |date=10 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111014631/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=244302743 |archivedate=11 November 2013 }} According to the SOHR, 63 rebels, including at least 11 foreign fighters, and 32 soldiers were killed during the battle. One other report put the number of rebels killed between 60 and 80.{{cite web|url=http://cphpost.dk/international/two-danes-allegedly-die-fighting-syria |title=Two Danes allegedly die fighting in Syria |publisher=Wayback.archive.org |date=13 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113121935/http://cphpost.dk/international/two-danes-allegedly-die-fighting-syria |archivedate=13 November 2013 }} Army units were backed-up by Hezbollah fighters and pro-government militias during the assault.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gz6wr66r6Oa38fRV4RQH7uwZd2pA?docId=7ab4cb0a-40ef-49b8-b757-5b337a3ee3a0&hl=en |title=Syria army retakes key base near Aleppo: state TV |publisher=Wayback.archive.org |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140315150531/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gz6wr66r6Oa38fRV4RQH7uwZd2pA?docId=7ab4cb0a-40ef-49b8-b757-5b337a3ee3a0&hl=en |archivedate=15 March 2014 }} By 11 November, the military had captured a series of nearby positions,{{cite web|author=Diaa Hadid |url=http://www.nwherald.com/2013/11/11/syria-based-groups-say-talks-may-be-last-chance/a8ppwjk/ |title=Syria-based groups say talks may be 'last chance' |publisher=Nwherald.com |date=11 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} securing most of the area around Aleppo International Airport.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2013/Nov-11/237517-syria-army-seeks-to-reopen-aleppo-airport-military.ashx#axzz2kLOt6xon |title=Syria army seeks to reopen Aleppo airport: military |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014}} === Aleppo's eastern approach and attack on Tell Hassel === On 12 November, the Syrian Army had penetrated the town of al-Naqqarin in the eastern outskirts of Aleppo city, advancing further north. Opposition activists said the Army "launched a pincer movement from the north and the east and were closing in on major rebel held neighborhoods". At the same time, government forces inside the city, backed by tanks, had taken two highrise buildings in the northern Ashrafieh and Bani Zeid districts, and advanced into the two neighbourhoods after close-quarter street fighting.{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/11/12/syria-crisis-aleppo-idUKL5N0IX4BS20131112 |title=Boosted by foreign Shi'ite militia, Assad's forces advance on Aleppo |publisher=Uk.reuters.com |date=12 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} On 13 November, [[Syrian Air Force]] helicopters dropped barrel bombs on rebel positions in Tell Hassel, south of Aleppo,{{cite web|author=RYAN LUCAS Associated Press |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/syrian-troops-rebels-clash-south-damascus-20862696 |title=Syrian Troops Make Inroads South of Damascus |publisher=Wayback.archive.org |date=12 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114054103/http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/syrian-troops-rebels-clash-south-damascus-20862696 |archivedate=14 November 2013 }} while the military advanced toward the town and fighting raged near it.{{cite web|url=http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/?id=62573 |title=Jihadists call for mass mobilisation to counter army advances in north Syria |publisher=Middle-east-online.com |date=13 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jgjqXCmuwr4UFF4iJS4h653Nu7ig?docId=32cb00c4-4218-4b94-88e2-b3d86e0a4231 |title=Army advances as jihadists call to arms in north Syria |publisher=Wayback.archive.org |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140226074158/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jgjqXCmuwr4UFF4iJS4h653Nu7ig?docId=32cb00c4-4218-4b94-88e2-b3d86e0a4231 |archivedate=26 February 2014 }} On 14 November, an air strike killed the intelligence commander of the rebel [[Al-Tawhid Brigade]] and wounded the top leader of the unit, while they were meeting at a base in Aleppo. One other commander was also injured.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/15/us-syria-crisis-aleppo-idUSBRE9AE04320131115 |title=Syrian air raid kills rebel commander in Aleppo: activists |publisher=Reuters.com |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014}} That night, the leader of the Al-Tawhid Brigade, Abdulkader al-Saleh, died of his wounds in Turkey. However, his death was kept secret for four days until he could be buried.{{cite web|author=James Reynolds |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-24984365 |title=Top Syrian rebel commander Abdul Qadir al-Saleh dies |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=18 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/19/world/middleeast/syria.html |title=Syrian Rebel Leader Dies After Government Attack|date=18 November 2013}} On 15 November, the military captured Tell Hassel,{{cite web|last=Evans |first=Dominic |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/15/us-syria-crisis-aleppo-idUSBRE9AE11X20131115 |title=Assad's forces advance in northern Syria towards Aleppo |publisher=Reuters.com |date=15 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/825182.shtml#.UoYFFeXtXy0 |title=Syrian troops regain town in southeast of Aleppo |publisher=Globaltimes.cn |date=15 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} with the rebels retreating to one of their strongholds near the town. By the end of the day, government forces secured the al-Safira road that connects Aleppo with the defence factories on the outskirts of al-Safira.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} The same day, a former Army colonel, who commanded another rebel brigade, was killed in fighting in the Maaret al-Artiq area, northwest of Aleppo city.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/86539/World/Region/Syria-air-strike-hits-Islamist-brigade-leadership.aspx |title=Syria air strike hits Islamist brigade leadership |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=15 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2013/Nov-16/238022-syrian-regime-forces-target-rebel-commanders.ashx#axzz2k3r8IiK5 |title=Syrian regime forces target rebel commanders |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014}} On 17 November, rebels blew up a bridge linking Tell Hassel and the cable, battery and tractor factories, which were still under rebel control, halting the military motorcade that was advancing towards the plants. Another military motorcade was reportedly advancing towards the rebel-held town of Bellat on the Aleppo-al-Bab highway. Later, government sources reported the Army managed to capture the factory area.{{cite web|url=http://abna.ir/data.asp?lang=3&Id=481871 |title=Militants Flee Strategic Region in Aleppo Countryside |publisher=Wayback.archive.org |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203022704/http://abna.ir/data.asp?lang=3&Id=481871 |archivedate=3 December 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://breakingnews.sy/en/article/29195.html |title=Syrian Arab Army advances in Aleppo… Civilians martyred and injured in an attack, Damascus |publisher=Breakingnews.sy |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014}} According to local activists, opposition forces started to retreat from the village of al-Duwayrinah and the industrial area adjacent to Tell Hassel.{{cite web|author=Joud Hassoun Karima Ward |url=http://syrianewsdesk.com/en/2013/11/17/news-regime-forces-advance-southern-aleppo-front |title=Regime forces advance on southern Aleppo front |publisher=Syrianewsdesk.com |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014}} The same day, a group of 15 ISIS rebel fighters conducted a raid into Tell Aran, which led to fighting that left 10 of the fighters dead as well as 18 government soldiers. The fate of the other five rebels remained unknown.{{cite web|author=|url=http://supportkurds.org/news/monday-18-november-2013/ |title=Monday 18 November 2013 |publisher=Supportkurds.org |date=19 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} On 18 November, fighting still raged in al-Naqqarin, on the eastern edge of Aleppo,{{cite web|last=Yacoub |first=Khaled |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/18/us-syria-crisis-idUSBRE9AH0NU20131118 |title=Syria rebel chieftain killed; Assad forces bomb besieged town |publisher=Reuters.com |date=18 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} while on 19 November, the Army captured al-Duwayrinah.{{cite web|author=Thomson Reuters Foundation |url=http://www.trust.org/item/20131119145959-vur9p/?source=search |title=Forces loyal to Syria's President Bashar al-Assad carry their weapons as they look on the ground in al-Dwayrineh village near the main highway leading Aleppo to Raqqa after capturing it from rebels |publisher=Trust.org |date=19 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} By 24 November, it was reported that government forces started a push into the [[Sheikh Najjar]] industrial zone in the northeastern part of Aleppo.{{cite web |author=Edward Dark Columnist |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2013/11/aleppo-regime-offensive-rebels-isis-syria.html |title=Aleppo gears for major regime offensive |publisher=Al-monitor.com |date=24 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808084233/http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2013/11/aleppo-regime-offensive-rebels-isis-syria.html |archive-date=8 August 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} On 30 November, Army helicopters targeted a rebel compound in al-Bab, but missed their target and hit a market, killing 26 people, including four children. The next day, the helicopters once again attacked the town, targeting a compound of the Tawhid Brigade, but missed their target and hit the Nafasin market instead, killing 24 people.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/2013/12/01/6783 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203041132/http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/2013/12/01/6783 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 December 2013 |title=50 killed in air strikes on Syrias Al-Bab |publisher=Thefinancialexpress-bd.com |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014 }} Most of those killed in the second attack were civilians, but also included three rebel fighters. In both attacks, the helicopters dropped barrel bombs.{{cite web|author=BARA SURK Associated Press |url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2013/dec/01/activists-death-toll-up-to-26-in-syrian-strike/ |title=Activists: New Syrian strike near Aleppo kills 11 |publisher=Utsandiego.com |date=1 December 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} At the beginning of December, it was confirmed the Army captured al-Naqqarin and was advancing towards [[Tiyara]]. Meanwhile, rebels were retreating from the Sheikh Najjar industrial area, especially from the "Zone 3" buildings, after the military took control of Sheikh Yusuf hill, which overlooks Zone 3.{{cite web |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/security/2013/12/syria-opposition-regime-spy-phobia.html# |title=Syrian opposition searches for regime spies |publisher=Al-monitor.com |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140220071256/http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/security/2013/12/syria-opposition-regime-spy-phobia.html |archive-date=20 February 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} On 1 December, [[Sama TV]] reported that the Army managed to capture the town of Tiyara, northeast of the al-Nairab air base, showing images of SAA soldiers inside the town.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cwD0__rG8uc حلب - قرية تيارا في منطقة جبل سمعان آمنة .. وتقدم الجيش مستمر] [[Sama TV]], 2 December 2013 === Attempted rebel counter-attack === On 21 November 15 government militiamen were killed fighting rebels near Base 80.{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20131121-fighting-aleppo-base-kills-15-syria-militia-ngo |title=Fighting for Aleppo base kills 15 Syria militia: NGO |publisher=Wayback.archive.org |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103072114/http://www.france24.com/en/20131121-fighting-aleppo-base-kills-15-syria-militia-ngo |archivedate=3 January 2014 }} A rebel commander was among the dead on the opposition's side.{{cite web|url=http://sherifazuhur.wordpress.com/tag/damascus/ |title=Syria Update, November 25, 2013 (Institute of Middle Eastern, Islamic and Strategic Studies. By Sherifa Zuhur) |publisher=Sherifazuhur.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014}} On 25 November, rebels started a counter-attack in the area around [[Khanasser]].{{cite web|url=http://www.yourmiddleeast.com/news/syria-rebels-press-advance-around-damascus-and-aleppo_19701 |title=Syria rebels press advance around Damascus and Aleppo |publisher=Yourmiddleeast.com |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014}} By the next day, the rebels managed to capture several villages, but were not able to block the highway to prevent a further Army advance.{{cite web|last=Solomon |first=Erika |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/26/us-syria-crisis-talks-rebels-idUSBRE9AP0BB20131126 |title=Free Syrian Army says no ceasefire for Geneva talks |publisher=Reuters.com |date=26 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} Days later, the Army recaptured the six villages that rebel forces managed to seize. On 28 November, government and rebel forces clashed in the outskirts of Aziza, west of the airport, leaving 20 government fighters and 11 rebels dead.{{cite web|author=|url=http://supportkurds.org/news/thursday-28-november-2013/ |title=Thursday 28 November 2013 |publisher=Supportkurds.org |date=29 November 2013 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} == Aftermath == {{main|Operation Canopus Star}} Soon after, the military launched operation ''Canopus Star'',{{cite web|url=http://www.syrianperspective.com/2013/12/first-post-december-9-2013-al-nabak-liberated-jihadist-terrorists-crushed-in-damascus-terrorist-leader-killed-in-east-ghouta-by-saa-massive-operation-canopus-star-grinds-rats-in.html|title=AL-NABAK LIBERATED!!; JIHADIST TERRORISTS CRUSHED IN DAMASCUS; TERRORIST LEADER KILLED IN EAST GHOUTA BY SAA; MASSIVE OPERATION "CANOPUS STAR" GRINDS RATS IN ALEPPO; NEWS AND COMMENTARY; WILE E. COYOTE MOMENT|author=Ziad Fadel|date=9 December 2013|work=Syrian Perspective}} with the aim to encircle Aleppo and cut rebel supply lines into the city, thus besieging rebel-held areas.{{cite web |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/security/2014/03/syria-army-impose-blockade-militants-aleppo.html# |title=Syrian army to impose blockade in Aleppo |publisher=Al-monitor.com |date= |accessdate=29 May 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150713202354/http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/security/2014/03/syria-army-impose-blockade-militants-aleppo.html |archive-date=13 July 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Subsequently, the Army broke the siege of Aleppo's central prison on 22 May,{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/syria-army-breaks-rebel-siege-of-aleppo-central-prison-ngo.aspx?pageID=238&nID=66804&NewsCatID=352 |title=Syria army breaks rebel siege of Aleppo central prison: NGO |publisher=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=13 September 2011 |accessdate=29 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/05/22/Syrian-troops-reach-besieged-Aleppo-prison.html |title=Syrian troops reach besieged Aleppo prison |publisher= |date= |accessdate=30 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/May-22/257379-syrian-troops-reach-besieged-prison-in-aleppo.ashx |title=Assad's forces enter Syria's Aleppo prison: activists |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date=22 May 2014 |accessdate=29 May 2014}} and on 3 July, government forces fully captured the Sheikh Najjar industrial district.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/xinhua-news-agency/140703/syrian-army-recaptures-aleppos-industrial-city|title=Syrian army recaptures Aleppo's industrial city|work=GlobalPost}} == See also == {{portal|Syrian civil war}} * [[Battle of Aleppo (2012–2016)]] * [[Battle of al-Qusayr (2013)]] * [[Rif Dimashq offensive (September–November 2013)]] == External links == *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_VtbmBGfN9w Syria War: The Decisive Battle 1: Darayya & Aleppo] [[Press TV]] documentary on [[YouTube]] *[http://vimeo.com/69872432 Documentary: The Decisive Battle 2] [[Press TV]] documentary on [[Vimeo]] == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Syrian civil war}} {{Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aleppo offensive (October-December 2013)}} [[Category:Aleppo in the Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War in 2013|Aleppo]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the Free Syrian Army]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Aleppo]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the al-Nusra Front|Aleppo]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the Syrian government]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving Hezbollah|Aleppo]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=October 2015}} '''Animasyros''' is an international [[animation]] festival and forum. Since 2008 the festival takes place in the capital of [[Cyclades]], [[Hermoupolis]] of [[Syros]], and includes animation movies screenings, special tributes to international festivals, professional forum with the participation of distinguished Greek and foreign creators and professionals, workshops for students and children, the applied follow-up workshop “making of”, parties and other parallel events.
== History == Each year the festival is enriched by new and original events, focused on social issues, such as [[domestic violence]], the status of women, [[racism]], etc. All events are free and are held in venues of the island, such as the Apollon Theatre, the municipal Cultural Centre, the local cinema. In 2014 open-air screenings began to take place on [[Miaoulis Square]]. Animasyros is the largest animation festival in [[Greece]] and one of the 20 largest of its kind in [[Europe]]. In 2014 the festival joined the European Project “[[Creative Europe]]”, which was designed to support millions of artists and professionals in the cultural field and to offer a new impulse on the cultural sector of Europe, and took advantage of its resources. Aim of the festival has from the early beginning been to show how a relatively new form of art in [[Greece]], as animation, can be adopted by the Greek art scene as well as to present significant creators. The selection of the event venue was made in connection to the fact that a society full of urban culture, such as [[Hermoupolis]]’ one, can enfold an initiative, which is gradually transformed from a local one to an international. In 2014 Animasyros joined, after a decision taken by [[Syros]]- Hermoupolis’ City Council, the task group that will create and establish the proposal of the nomination “Syros- Cyclades 2021” - [[Cultural Capital of Europe]].
== International participation == The festival has gradually become an attraction spot for tens of significant artists and animation schools. In the past outstanding schools, festivals as well as representatives of award-winning animation production companies participated in the happenings and tributes of Animasyros. Owing to the festival, artists like [[Nina Paley]], Jim Capobianco, Ülo Pikkov, Patrick Smith, Marie-Margaux Tsakiri-Scanatovits, Alain Baran, as well as representatives of production companies, such as [[LAIKA]], [[Pixar]] and [[Dreamworks]], and international festivals, such as Anima Brussels International Animation Film Festival, Canterbury Anifest, Annecy International Festival of Animated Film, Trickfilm festival, Hiroshima international animation festival, [[Anifest]], [[Animafest Zagreb]] etc., visited [[Syros]]. Furthermore, the festival program has occasionally included special tributes to artists like [[Signe Baumane]], Jacques- Rémy Girerd etc.
== Greek participation and workshops == Greek animation scene is represented each year in the festival with special tributes as well as through the competition section, which highlights any notable creative effort. Throughout the seven years of the festival, prominent creators like Aggelos Spartalis, Helen Miltsi, Effie Pappa etc. have distinguished. At the same time, Animasyros runs a student competition sector, which constitutes a great chance for new talents to emerge. Greek animation artists and teachers like Christine Depian, Helen Mouri, Giannis Xagoraris, Constantinos Tiligades etc. undertake to teach in the workshops of Animasyros and host tens of animation fans. The free educational programs of the festival, including both children and applied workshops, cover the largest possible range of creation fields.
== Mascot, production and supporters == The mascot of the festival is “AnimaSpyros”; a [[Cycladic]] figure with references to director [[Woody Allen]]. “AnimaSpyros” was designed by Petros Christoulias and developed in three dimensions by Constantinos Petrou. Since 2008 has accompanied all festival events and reminds us of both the origin and the concept of the festival. Animasyros is organized by PLATFORMA – Company of Urban Culture. The production team of the festival consists of above fifty members, who apart from coordinating and managing the event are also dealing with artistic and technical issues, such as animation, graphic design, direction, photography, multimedia etc. Additionally, valuable partners of the festival are the volunteers –around fifty on average- who contribute to the accomplishment of all Animasyros events. Animasyros is set every year under the auspices of the Municipality of Syros- Hermoupolis, the [[South Aegean Region]], whereas receives the active support of both public, such as the General Secretariat for Gender Equality, the Ministry of Tourism, the [[University of Aegean]], and private institutions, such as [[Onassis Foundation|Onassis Cultural Centre]], the [[Benaki Museum]] etc. Supporters of the festival are also on a regular basis educational departments of foreign embassies in [[Greece]]. The involvement of the local business community of the island has all these seven years been at a high level. Local authorities have confronted the festival from the early beginning with great respect, since except of its artistic dynamic the festival has contributed to the extension of the island’s touristic season as well as has presented the island as a high standards’ touristic destination. The participation in all the activities and screenings of Animasyros is free.
== Animasyros7 == The festival reached its seven years of active presence in 2014. The happenings of Animasyros7, which were held from 2 to 5 October, included for a first time open-air screenings on [[Miaoulis Square]], executed with the use of special technical equipment. This year’s screenings and parallel events attracted more than 3.000 visitors, both [[Greek people|Greek]] and foreign. The happenings of Animasyros7 opened for a first time with a special ceremony at the [[Benaki Museum]] in [[Athens]], where a presentation of this year’s events and screenings as well as an overall assessment of Animasyros6 took place. Guests of this event were, among others, [[Mark Shapiro (animator)|Mark Shapiro]], representative of [[Laika (company)|LAIKA]] Studio, creator [[Nina Paley]]<ref>http://www.zippyframes.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2146:nina-paley-talks-animation-the-prophet-and-animasyros-fest&catid=97:interviews&Itemid=100010</ref> along with representatives of the American Embassy in [[Athens]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://athens.usembassy.gov/animasyros.html# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2014-10-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141028233037/http://athens.usembassy.gov/animasyros.html# |archive-date=2014-10-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> which is an ardent supporter of the festival. As far as the artistic part is concerned, Animasyros included more than one hundred screenings, special guests from the U.S., the [[Great Britain]], [[France]] and other countries, thematic workshops for elementary students, young and older animation fans, whereas a nationwide premiere of the new production of the award-winning animation studio [[LAIKA]], “[[The Boxtrolls]]”, was held. For four whole days, Hermoupolis experienced the spirit of the animation world. As a [[Neoclassical architecture|neoclassical]] city, [[Hermoupolis]], resembled to animation movie scenery along with the 150 years old Apollon Theatre and the enthusiastic audience (students, professionals, journalists, natives of all ages, parents carrying their children within the theatre’s hall). The age spectrum was even more astonishing as far as artistic attainments of the workshops are concerned; animation students accompanied by professional teachers introduced young students of [[Hermoupolis]] to how the art of animation is executed and produced small samples of animation work.<ref>http://flix.gr/news/animasyros-70.html</ref>
Animasyros7 awards were given as follows: # Grand prize of Animasyros 7.0 was given to “[[Historia de un oso]]” from [[Chile]] # Special Mention to a Greek Film in Student Competition Program was given to “Man in a box” by llias Papastamatiou # Special Mention in Student Competition was given to “Mythopolis” by Alexandra Hetmerova from [[Czech Republic]] # Best Student Film was given to “My stuffed granny” by Effie Pappa from the UK # Special Mention to a Greek film in International Competition Program was given to “Dinner for few” by [[Nassos Vakalis]] # Special Mention to a film in International Competition Program was given to “Canis” by Marc Riba & Anna Solanas
In 2014 the festival was accompanied by special tributes targeted both to raise the awareness of the public opinion and to disseminate the perspective of the big schools of European animation to the festival’s audience. The festival honored in 2014 women creators as well as the female element in the art of animation. Therefore, a tribute to gender equality was carried out under the auspices of the General Secretariat for Gender Equality and the American Embassy in [[Athens]]. The tribute entitled “Woman in Anima” included movies screenings by internationally renowned artist [[Signe Baumane]], whose work is focused on modern woman issues, such as the recently awarded film “Rocks in my pockets”, as well as movies like “Sita sings the blues” by [[Nina Paley]]. Furthermore, the festival hosted this year special and enriched tributes with European orientation. With the support of the Institut Francais de Athenes (IFA), the festival realized a tribute to the great creator of animation movies Jacques-Rémy Girerd, founder of the famous studio [[Folimage]]. With reference to the north of Europe other significant events were also held within the festival; the tribute to [[Animafest Zagreb]] from [[Croatia]], which since its establishment in 1972 is the second oldest animation festival in [[Europe]], as well as the tributes to [[Tallinn]] [[Tallinn Black Nights Film Festival|Black Nights Film Festival]] and to Animated Dreams sub-festival, which both count more than fifteen years of active presence and come from the particularly active in [[animation]] production country of [[Estonia]].
== Animasyros and European Cultural Capital 2021 Project == In the summer of 2014 the first contacts between Animasyros and local authorities of [[Syros]] began in order to discuss the possibility of Animasyros involvement in the preparation proceedings of the nomination of the Municipality of Syros as [[Cultural Capital of Europe]] 2021. In October 2014, an official task group was created with the participation of the local authorities as well as institutions linked to cultural and touristic affairs, so as a nomination proposal entitled “Syros- Cyclades 2021 – [[Cultural Capital of Europe]]” to be formed. Animasyros became part of this group and now works towards drafting and promoting the nomimation, recognizing the uniqueness of Hermoupolis as well as of the whole archipelago as an integral monument of European cultural reference.<ref>https://diavgeia.gov.gr/search?query=q:%22animasyros%22&page=1&sort=relative</ref> At the same time, Animasyros strongly supports every initiative taken by the Municipality in its effort to get the historic site of Hermoupolis and the medieval settlement of [[Ano Syros]] included in the [[Unesco]] [[World Heritage List]] as the 18th Greek monument.
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== Sources - external links == * https://web.archive.org/web/20141028201717/http://www.animasyros.gr/index.php/GR/ * http://ec.europa.eu/programmes/creative-europe/index_en.htm * https://web.archive.org/web/20141016031422/http://www.hermoupolis.gr/ * http://athens.usembassy.gov/animasyros.htm{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * http://www.portheraklion.gr/index.php/el/see-feelsmell/animasyros-70-die8nes-festibal-foroym-kinoymenwn-sxediwn-dia/ * http://laika.com/ * http://www.animation-festivals.com/festivals/animasyros/ * http://www.syrostoday.gr/News/12670-7o-Festival-Anima-Syros-2014-Sti-Syro.aspx * https://web.archive.org/web/20141103183544/http://cyclades24.gr/2014-01-15-09-42-24/2014-01-15-10-12-07/2014-01-15-10-06-54/item/14884-to-anima-syros-7-0-sto-deltio-eidisewn-tou-mega.html * http://www.filmfestivals.com/festival/animasyros_international_animation_festival * http://www.inbulb.com/
