revision.text:
{{coord|35|32|04.35|N|139|43|28.67|E|scale:2000|display=title}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Kanamara Matsuri |type = shinto |image = Kanamara Matsuri 2007 (phallus festival)-crop.jpg |imagesize = 250px |caption = A crowd gathers at Kanamara Matsuri festival. |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = Kanayama shrine, [[Kawasaki, Kanagawa|Kawasaki]], [[Japan]] |litcolor = |longtype = Religious |significance = |begins = |ends = |scheduling = nth weekday of the month |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |week_ordinal = first |weekday = Sunday |month = April |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = }} The [[Shinto]] {{nihongo3|"Festival of the Steel Phallus"|かなまら祭り|'''Kanamara Matsuri'''}} is held each spring at the {{nihongo|'''Kanayama Shrine'''|金山神社|Kanayama-jinja}} in [[Kawasaki, Kanagawa|Kawasaki]], [[Japan]]. The exact dates vary: the main festivities fall on the first Sunday in April. The [[phallus]], as the central theme of the event, is reflected in illustrations, candy, carved vegetables, decorations, and a [[mikoshi]] parade.<ref name="cosmopolitan">{{cite web|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.co.uk/_mobile/celebs/entertainment/festival-steel-phallus-japan|title=Dammit, we missed The Festival of the Steel Phallus in Japan this weekend - Cosmopolitan|publisher=cosmopolitan.co.uk|accessdate=2014-04-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413125132/http://www.cosmopolitan.co.uk/_mobile/celebs/entertainment/festival-steel-phallus-japan|archivedate=2014-04-13|df=}}</ref><ref name="huffingtonpost">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/07/japan-penis-festival-kanamara-matsuri_n_5106378.html|title=Japan's Annual Penis Festival Is As Phallic As You'd Expect (PHOTOS)|author=Dominique Mosbergen|publisher=huffingtonpost.com|accessdate=2014-04-11}}</ref><ref name="timeslive">{{cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/lifestyle/2014/04/10/japanese-festival-celebrates-the-penis|title=Japanese festival celebrates the penis - Times LIVE|author=Times LIVE|publisher=timeslive.co.za|accessdate=2014-04-11}}</ref><ref name="abc">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/stories/s270563.htm|title=The World Today Archive - Japan's Festival of the Steel Phallus|publisher=abc.net.au|date=2001-04-02|accessdate=2014-04-11}}</ref><ref name="bbc">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/travel/slideshow/20140325-ten-exciting-events-not-to-miss-in-april |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140331232907/http://www.bbc.com/travel/slideshow/20140325-ten-exciting-events-not-to-miss-in-april |archive-date=2014-03-31 |dead-url=yes |title=BBC - Travel - Slideshow - Ten events not to miss in April|accessdate=2014-04-11}}</ref>
The Kanamara Matsuri is centered on a local [[penis]]-venerating shrine. The legend being that a jealous sharp-toothed demon hid inside the [[vagina]] of a young woman the demon fell in love with and bit off penises of two young men on their wedding nights.<ref name="huffingtonpost3">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/04/07/kanamara-matsuri-2014_n_5105892.html|title=Kanamara Matsuri 2014: What You Should Know About Japan's Penis Festival (NSFW PHOTOS)|publisher=huffingtonpost.ca|accessdate=2014-04-11}}</ref> After that the woman sought help from a blacksmith, who fashioned an iron [[phallus]] to break the demon's teeth, which led to the enshrinement of the item.<ref name="metropolis">{{cite web|url=http://archive.metropolis.co.jp/tokyotravel/tokyojapantravel/365/tokyojapantravelinc.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100406163730/http://archive.metropolis.co.jp/tokyotravel/tokyojapantravel/365/tokyojapantravelinc.htm |archive-date=2010-04-06 |dead-url=yes |title=Metropolis - Japan Travel: Kawasaki - Heads up |accessdate=2014-04-11 |df= }}</ref> This legend in [[Ainu language]] was published as "The Island of Women" by [[Basil Hall Chamberlain]]<ref>Chamberlain, B. H. "The Island of Women" ''Aino Folk-Tales'', 1888. pp. [[s:Aino Folk-Tales#vii|vii]], [[s:Aino Folk-Tales#37|37]].</ref>
The Kanayama Shrine was popular among [[prostitute]]s who wished to pray for protection from [[sexually transmitted infections]].<ref name="huffingtonpost2">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/04/04/kanamara-matsuri-penis-festival_n_5087119.html|title=Kanamara Matsuri: When Does Japan's Penis Festival Start? (NSFW PHOTOS)|publisher=huffingtonpost.ca|accessdate=2014-04-11}}</ref>
It is also said the shrine offers divine protections for business prosperity, and for the clan's prosperity; and for easy delivery, marriage, and married-couple harmony.{{cn|date=May 2016}}
The festival started in 1969.<ref name=php>[https://books.google.co.jp/books?id=UIKLK5rdt-wC&pg=RA1-PA47 世界も驚くニッポン旅行100: テーマでめぐる!47都道府県ローカル旅] PHP研究所, Jul 4, 2013</ref> Today, the festival has become something of a tourist attraction and is used to raise money for [[HIV]] research.<ref name="heraldsun">{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/travel/photos-fn2wzol2-1225975486025?page=4 |title=Kanamara-Matsuri {{!}} World's weirdest festivals |publisher=Herald Sun <!--|archive-url=archive.is/kOBO9#selection-751.10-751.29 |archive-date=April 10, 2014-->}} {{dead link|date=April 2016}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery mode="packed" heights="200px"> File:Kanamara-mikoshi2.jpg File:Kanamara-mikoshi3.jpg File:Kanamara-mikoshi1.jpg File:Elizabeth-mikoshi.jpg File:Peniscandy.jpg </gallery>
==See also== *[[Vagina dentata]] *[[Hōnen Matsuri]] (Harvest Festival), whose main features include a 2.5 meter-long wooden phallus *[[Phallic processions]] *[[Tyrnavos]], a city in Greece that holds an annual Phallus festival *[[Ōkunitama Shrine]] (friendship shrine)

page.title: List of CMLL tag team tournaments

revision.text:
The Mexican [[professional wrestling promotion]] [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL) has held a number of tournaments [[tag team]] or their "Trios" (three man teams) divisions over the years. Some of the tournaments were recurring, but have not been held in the last two to three years and others were one-off tournament held for a special event. Being professional wrestling tournaments, they are not won legitimately through competitive matches; instead they are won via predetermined outcomes to the matches that is generally kept secret from the general public. ==Copa de Arena Mexico== CMLL held three tournaments under the name ''Copa de Arena Mexico'', named after their main venue [[Arena Mexico]], where all the tournaments also took place. The tournament was held in 1999, 2001 and 2002. ;Copa de Arena Mexico winners {| class="wikitable" width=50% !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Year !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Winner !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Date !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Note |- |[[#Copa de Arena Mexico 1999|1999]] |"''[[Los Guerreros del Infierno]]''"
{{nobr|[[El Satánico]], [[Rey Bucanero]] and [[Último Guerrero]]}} |{{dts|1999|12|10}} | |- |[[#Copa de Arena Mexico 2001|2001]] |"Team Shocker"
{{nobr|[[Black Warrior (wrestler)|Black Warrior]], [[Shocker (wrestler)|Shocker]], and [[Apolo Dantés]]}} |{{dts|2001|12|28}} | |- |[[#Copa de Arena Mexico 2002|2002]] |"Team Tall"
{{nobr|[[Black Warrior (wrestler)|Black Warrior]], [[Lizmark Jr.]], and [[Rayo de Jalisco Jr.]]}} |{{dts|2002|7|5}} | |} ===Copa de Arena Mexico 1999=== {{Infobox wrestling event |name=Copa de Area Mexico (1999) |image= |caption= |promotion = [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] |date={{dts|1999|12|10}} |attendance= |venue=[[Arena Mexico]] |city = [[Mexico City|Mexico City, Mexico]] |liveevent=Y |lastevent=''[[Leyenda de Plata#Leyenda de Plata 1999|Leyenda de Plata]]'' (1999) |nextevent=''[[CMLL Torneo Gran Alternativa#Gran Alternativa 1999 (II)|Gran Alternativa]]'' (1999 #2) |event=''Copa de Arena Mexico'' |lastevent2=First |nextevent2=''[[List of CMLL tag team tournaments#Copa de Arena Mexico 2001|Copa de Arena Mexico]]'' (2001) }} The first ''Copa de Arena Mexico'' tournament was a one night, four team single-elimination tournament was held on December 10, 1999 and was also called ''Torneo Siglo XXI'' ("21st Century Tournament"). The tournament was won by "''[[Los Infernales|Los Guerreros del Infierno]]''" ([[El Satánico]], [[Rey Bucanero]] and [[Último Guerrero]]), a team name that Bucanero and Guerrero would later use when they split from El Satánico to form their own faction. The winners were given a trophy but no other tangible award was given as a result of the victory. The tournament included four teams who all teamed on a regular basis both before and after the tournament.{{cite book|author=Royal Duncan and Gary Will|title=Wrestling Title Histories|publisher=Archeus Communications|chapter=Mexico: Copa de Arena Mexico|page=397|year=2000|isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} ;Tournament Participants *"''Los Guapos''": [[Bestia Salvaje]], [[Scorpio Jr.]] and [[Shocker (wrestler)|Shocker]] *"''[[Los Infernales|Los Guerreros del Infierno]]''": [[El Satánico]], [[Rey Bucanero]] and [[Último Guerrero]] (Tournament winners) *"Team Casas": [[Negro Casas]], [[El Felino]] and [[Antifaz del Norte]] *"Team Emilio": [[Emilio Charles Jr.]], [[Mr. Niebla]] and [[Toscano (wrestler)|Tarzan Boy]] ;Tournament brackets {{4TeamBracket | team-width=100em | RD1-team1=Team Casas | RD1-score1= | RD1-team2='''Los Guerreros del Infierno''' | RD1-score2=W | RD1-team3=Los Guapos | RD1-score3= | RD1-team4='''Team Emilio''' | RD1-score4=W | RD2-team1='''Los Guerreros del Infierno''' | RD2-score1=W | RD2-team2=Team Emilio | RD2-score2= }} ===Copa de Arena Mexico 2001=== {{Infobox wrestling event |name=Copa de Arena Mexico (2001) |image= |caption= |promotion = [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] |date={{dts|2002|7|5}} |attendance= |venue=[[Arena Mexico]] |city = [[Mexico City|Mexico City, Mexico]] |liveevent=Y |lastevent=''[[Sin Piedad (2001)|Sin Piedad]]'' (2001) |nextevent=''[[Homenaje a Dos Leyendas: El Santo y Salvador Lutteroth (2002)|Homenaje a Dos Leyendas]]'' (2002) |event=''Copa de Arena Mexico'' |lastevent2=''[[List of CMLL tag team tournaments#Copa de Arena Mexico 1999|Copa de Arena Mexico]]'' (1999) |nextevent2=''[[List of CMLL tag team tournaments#Copa de Arena Mexico 2002|Copa de Arena Mexico]]'' (2002) }} The second ''Copa de Arena Mexico'' tournament was once again a one night single-elimination tournament, this time with eight teams instead of four. The tournament was held on December 28, 2001 and was won by "Team Shocker" ([[Black Warrior (wrestler)|Black Warrior]], [[Shocker (wrestler)|Shocker]], and [[Apolo Dantés]]). The winners were given a trophy but no other tangible award was given as a result of the victory. Some of the teams in the tournament worked together on a regular basis, others were created for the tournament.{{cite news|author=Box y Lucha staff|title=2001 Especial!|work=Box y Lucha Magazine|pages=10–25|id=2540|date=January 13, 2002|language=Spanish}} ;Tournament Participants *[[Los Boricuas (CMLL)|Team Boricua]]: [[Gran Markus Jr.]], [[The Killer (wrestler)|The Killer]], [[Bestia Salvaje]] *Team Brazo: [[Brazo de Plata]], [[Brazo de Oro (wrestler)|Brazo de Oro]] and [[Brazo de Platino]] *Team Casas: [[Negro Casas]], [[El Felino]] and [[La Fiera]] *Team Demon: [[Blue Demon Jr.]], [[Mr. Niebla]] and [[Starman (wrestler)|Starman]] *Team ''[[Los Guerreros del Infierno|Guerreros del Infierno]]'': [[Silver King (wrestler)|Black Tiger]], [[Rey Bucanero]] and [[Antonio Gómez Medina|Máscara Mágica]] *Team ''[[Los Infernales|Infernal]]'': [[El Satánico]], [[Averno (wrestler)|Averno]] and [[Mephisto (wrestler)|Mephisto]] *Team Shocker: [[Shocker (wrestler)|Shocker]], [[Apolo Dantés]] and [[Black Warrior (wrestler)|Black Warrior]] *Team ''Villano'': [[Villano III]], [[Villano IV]] and [[Villano V]] ;Tournament brackets {{8TeamBracket | team-width=100em | RD1-team1=Team Casas | RD1-score1= | RD1-team2='''Team Guerreros del Infierno''' | RD1-score2=W | RD1-team3=Team Demon | RD1-score3= | RD1-team4='''Team Shocker''' | RD1-score4=W | RD1-team5=Team Boricuas | RD1-score5= | RD1-team6='''Team Brazos''' | RD1-score6=W | RD1-team7=Team Infernal | RD1-score7= | RD1-team8='''Team Villano''' | RD1-score8=W | RD2-team1=Team Guerreros del Infierno | RD2-score1= | RD2-team2='''Team Shocker''' | RD2-score2=W | RD2-team3='''Team Brazos''' | RD2-score3=W | RD2-team4=Team Villano | RD2-score4= | RD3-team1=Team Brazos | RD3-score1= | RD3-team2='''Team Shocker''' | RD3-score2=W }} ===Copa de Arena Mexico 2002=== {{Infobox wrestling event |name=Copa de Arena Mexico (2002) |image= |caption= |promotion = [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] |date={{dts|2002|7|5}} |attendance= |venue=[[Arena Mexico]] |city = [[Mexico City|Mexico City, Mexico]] |liveevent=Y |lastevent=''[[Aniversario de Arena México#46. Aniversario de Arena México|46. Aniversario de Arena México]]'' |nextevent=''[[Leyenda de Plata#Leyenda de Plata 2002|Leyenda de Plata]]'' (2002) |event=''Copa de Arena Mexico'' |lastevent2=''[[List of CMLL tag team tournaments#Copa de Arena Mexico 2001|Copa de Arena Mexico]]'' (2001) |nextevent2=Last }} The third and last ''Copa de Arena Mexico'' tournament was a one night eight team single-elimination tournament, held on July 5, 2002 and was won by "Team Tall" ([[Black Warrior (wrestler)|Black Warrior]], [[Lizmark Jr.]], and [[Rayo de Jalisco Jr.]]). The win made Black Warrior the only wrestler to win the tournament more than once. The winners were given a trophy but no other tangible award was given as a result of the victory. Some of the teams in the tournament worked together on a regular basis, others were created for the tournament. Team Giant only consisted of two members, [[Giant Silva]] and [[Mr. Niebla]], due to the size of Giant Silva CMLL counted him as two wrestlers for this tournament and most of the matches he participated in.{{cite news|title=2002: considerar detrás|work=Box y Lucha Magazine|id=2593|date=January 19, 2003|language=Spanish}} ;Tournament Participants *Team Giant: [[Giganté Silva]] and [[Mr. Niebla]] *Team [[Los Infernales|Infernal]]: [[El Satánico]], [[Averno (wrestler)|Averno]] and [[Mephisto (wrestler)|Mephisto]] *Team Japan: [[Silver King (wrestler)|Black Tiger]], [[Kazuhiko Masada|Masada]] and [[Kazushige Nosawa|Nosawa]] *Team Mexico: [[Gran Markus Jr.]], [[Poder Mexica]] and Mr. Mexico *Team Shocker: [[Shocker (wrestler)|Shocker]], [[Antonio Gómez Medina|Máscara Mágica]] and [[Apolo Dantés]] *Team [[Taliban]]: [[Emilio Charles Jr.]], [[Scorpio Jr.]] and [[Bestia Salvaje]] *Team Tall: [[Rayo de Jalisco Jr.]], [[Black Warrior (wrestler)|Black Warrior]] and [[Lizmark Jr.]] *Team Villano: [[Villano III]], [[Villano IV]] and [[Villano V]] ;Tournament brackets {{8TeamBracket | team-width=100em | RD1-team1=Team Mexico | RD1-score1= | RD1-team2='''Team Japan''' | RD1-score2=W | RD1-team3=Team Infernal | RD1-score3= | RD1-team4='''Team Villano''' | RD1-score4=W | RD1-team5=Team Giant | RD1-score5= | RD1-team6='''Team Shocker''' | RD1-score6=W | RD1-team7=Team Infernal | RD1-score7= | RD1-team8='''Team Villano''' | RD1-score8=W | RD2-team1='''Team Tall''' | RD2-score1=W | RD2-team2=Team Taliban | RD2-score2= | RD2-team3=Team Shocker | RD2-score3= | RD2-team4='''Team Tall''' | RD2-score4=W | RD3-team1=Team Japan | RD3-score1= | RD3-team2='''Team Tall''' | RD3-score2=W }} ==Copa de Oro 1994== {{Infobox wrestling event |name=Copa de Oro (1994) |image= |caption= |promotion = [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] |date={{dts|1994|10|25}} |attendance= |venue=[[Arena Coliseo]] |city = [[Mexico City|Mexico City, Mexico]] |liveevent=Y |lastevent=[[CMLL 61st Anniversary Show]] |nextevent=''[[Torneo Gran Alternativa (1994)|Gran Alternativa]]'' (1994) |event=''Copa de Oro'' |lastevent2=First |nextevent2=''[[List of CMLL tag team tournaments#Copa de Oro 1995|Copa de Oro]]'' (1995) }} On October 26, 1993 [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL) wrestler [[Oro (wrestler)|Oro]] died as a direct result of a match at [[Arena Coliseo]]. The following year, on September 25, 1994 CMLL held a [[tag team]] tournament in [[Arena Coliseo]] to commemorate the loss of the popular wrestler and honor his memory. The tournament winners were presented with a trophy by [[Los Metálicos#Plata|Oro II]], the original Oro's brother who had taken the name out of respect. The tournament was an eight-team single elimination tournament won by [[Apolo Dantés]] and [[El Dandy]].{{cite book|author=Royal Duncan and Gary Will|title=Wrestling Title Histories|publisher=Archeus Communications|chapter=Mexico: Copa de Oro 1994|page=398|year=2000|isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} ;Tournament participants *[[Apolo Dantés]] and [[El Dandy]] *[[Brazo de Oro (wrestler)|Brazo de Oro]] and [[Brazo de Plata]] *[[Dr. Wagner Jr.]] and [[Gran Markus Jr.]] *[[Hayabusa (wrestler)|Hayabusa]] and [[Último Dragón]] *Javier Cruz and [[Cachorro Mendoza]] *[[La Fiera]] and [[Ringo Mendoza]] *[[Negro Casas]] and [[Emilio Charles Jr.]] *[[Pierroth Jr.]] and [[El Satánico]] ;Tournament brackets {{8TeamBracket | score-width=1em | team-width=100em | RD1-team1='''[[Apolo Dantés]] and [[El Dandy]]''' | RD1-score1=W | RD1-team2=[[Hayabusa (wrestler)|Hayabusa]] and [[Último Dragón]] | RD1-score2= | RD1-team3=Javier Cruz and [[Cachorro Mendoza]] | RD1-score3=W | RD1-team4='''[[Negro Casas]] and [[Emilio Charles Jr.]]''' | RD1-score4= | RD1-team5='''[[Pierroth Jr.]] and [[El Satánico]]''' | RD1-score5=W | RD1-team6=[[Brazo de Oro (wrestler)|Brazo de Oro]] and [[Brazo de Plata]] | RD1-score6= | RD1-team7='''[[La Fiera]] and [[Ringo Mendoza]]''' | RD1-score7=W | RD1-team8=[[Dr. Wagner Jr.]] and [[Gran Markus Jr.]] | RD1-score8= | RD2-team1='''[[Apolo Dantés]] and [[El Dandy]]''' | RD2-score1=W | RD2-team2=[[Negro Casas]] and [[Emilio Charles Jr.]] | RD2-score2= | RD2-team3='''[[Pierroth Jr.]] and [[El Satánico]]''' | RD2-score3=W | RD2-team4=[[La Fiera]] and [[Ringo Mendoza]] | RD2-score4= | RD3-team1='''[[Apolo Dantés]] and [[El Dandy]]''' | RD3-score1=W | RD3-team2=[[Pierroth Jr.]] and [[El Satánico]] | RD3-score2= }} ==Copa de Oro 1995== {{Infobox wrestling event |name=Copa de Oro (1995) |image= |caption= |promotion = [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] |date={{dts|1995|10|26}} |attendance= |venue=[[Arena Coliseo]] |city = [[Mexico City|Mexico City, Mexico]] |liveevent=Y |lastevent=[[CMLL 62nd Anniversary Show]] |nextevent=''[[La Copa Junior#La Copa Junior Tournament (1996)|La Copa Junior]]'' (1996) |event=''Copa de Oro'' |lastevent2=''[[List of CMLL tag team tournaments#Copa de Oro 1994|Copa de Oro]]'' (1994) |nextevent2=Last }} On October 26, 1993 [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL) wrestler [[Oro (wrestler)|Oro]] died as a direct result of a match at [[Arena Coliseo]]. CMLL held ''Copa de Oro'' one year later in 1994 and followed it with a second ''Copa de Oro'' in 1995 on October 24. The tournament winners were presented with a trophy by [[Los Metálicos#Plata|Oro II]], the original Oro's brother who had taken the name out of respect. The tournament was an eight-team single elimination tournament won by Chicago Express and [[Pierroth Jr.]]{{cite book|author=Royal Duncan and Gary Will|title=Wrestling Title Histories|publisher=Archeus Communications|chapter=Mexico: Copa de Oro 1995|page=398|year=2000|isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} ;Tournament participants *[[Américo Rocca]] and Javier Cruz *[[Bestia Salvaje]] and [[Sangre Chicana]] *[[Blue Demon Jr.]] and [[Silver King (wrestler)|Silver King]] *[[Brazo de Oro (wrestler)|Brazo de Oro]] and [[El Brazo]] *Chicago Express and [[Pierroth Jr.]] *[[Emilio Charles Jr.]] and [[El Felino]] *[[Gran Markus Jr.]] and [[Hijo del Gladiador]] *[[Antonio Gómez Medina|Máscara Mágica]] and [[Ringo Mendoza]] ;Tournament brackets {{8TeamBracket | score-width=1em | team-width=100em | RD1-team1='''[[Antonio Gómez Medina|Máscara Mágica]] and [[Ringo Mendoza]]''' | RD1-score1=W | RD1-team2=[[Bestia Salvaje]] and [[Sangre Chicana]] | RD1-score2= | RD1-team3=[[Blue Demon Jr.]] and [[Silver King (wrestler)|Silver King]] | RD1-score3= | RD1-team4='''[[Emilio Charles Jr.]] and [[El Felino]]''' | RD1-score4=W | RD1-team5='''[[Brazo de Oro (wrestler)|Brazo de Oro]] and [[El Brazo]]''' | RD1-score5=W | RD1-team6=[[Gran Markus Jr.]] and [[Hijo del Gladiador]] | RD1-score6= | RD1-team7='''Chicago Express and [[Pierroth Jr.]]''' | RD1-score7=W | RD1-team8=[[Américo Rocca]] and Javier Cruz | RD1-score8= | RD2-team1='''[[Antonio Gómez Medina|Máscara Mágica]] and [[Ringo Mendoza]]''' | RD2-score1=W | RD2-team2=[[Emilio Charles Jr.]] and [[El Felino]] | RD2-score2= | RD2-team3='''Chicago Express and [[Pierroth Jr.]]''' | RD2-score3=W | RD2-team4=[[Brazo de Oro (wrestler)|Brazo de Oro]] and [[El Brazo]] | RD2-score4= | RD3-team1=[[Antonio Gómez Medina|Máscara Mágica]] and [[Ringo Mendoza]] | RD3-score1= | RD3-team2='''Chicago Express and [[Pierroth Jr.]]''' | RD3-score2=W }} ==CMLL Second Generation Tag Team Tournament== {{Infobox wrestling event |name=Second Generation Tag Team Tournament |image= |caption= |promotion = [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] |date={{dts|1995|9|1}} |attendance= |venue=[[Arena Mexico]] |city = [[Mexico City|Mexico City, Mexico]] |liveevent=Y |lastevent=[[CMLL International Gran Prix#International Gran Prix 1995|International Gran Prix (1995)]] |nextevent=[[CMLL 62nd Anniversary Show]] }} Wrestling is a family tradition in [[Lucha libre]], with a large number of second or even third generation wrestlers following in the footsteps of their relatives. [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL) held a [[tag team]] tournament on September 1, 1995 to pay homage to the wrestling families by holding a tournament for second or third generation wrestlers. In a few cases the family relationship was not a blood relationship, but more of a storyline with the "Junior" wrestler either paying to use the name or being given the name by the "Senior". The winners got a trophy and no other tangible reward. The second generation concept led to CMLL creating the ''[[La Copa Junior]]'' tournament in early 1996.{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/emll/second.html#1996|title=Copa Junior Tournament 1996|date=February 23 – March 31, 1996|accessdate=October 20, 2012|publisher=Pro Wrestling History}} The CMLL Second Generation Tag Team Tournament was won by the team of [[Apolo Dantés]] and [[Emilio Charles Jr.]]{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/emll/second.html#1995|title=Copa Junior Tag Team Tournament 1995|date=September 1, 1995|accessdate=November 12, 2012|work=Pro Wrestling History}} ;Tournament Participants *[[Apolo Dantés]] and [[Emilio Charles Jr.]] *[[Blue Demon Jr.]] and [[Tinieblas Jr.]] *[[Brazo de Oro (wrestler)|Brazo de Oro]] and [[Brazo de Plata]] *[[Dr. Wagner Jr.]] and [[Gran Markus Jr.]] *[[El Hijo del Santo]] and [[Rayo de Jalisco Jr.]] *[[El Hijo del Solitario]] and [[El Solitario]] *[[Espectro Jr.]] and [[Pierroth Jr.]] *[[Karloff Lagarde Jr.]] and RD3-team1='''Apolo Dantés and Emilio Charles Jr.''' | RD3-score1=W | RD3-team2=Hijo del Santo and Rayo de Jalisco Jr. | RD3-score2= }} ==Salvador Lutteroth Trios Tournament== {{Infobox wrestling event |name=Salvador Lutteroth Trios Tournament |image= |caption= |promotion = [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] |date={{dts|1995|3|24}} |attendance= |venue=[[Arena Mexico]] |city = [[Mexico City|Mexico City, Mexico]] |liveevent=Y |lastevent=''[[CMLL Torneo Gran Alternativa#Gran Alternativa 1994|Torneo Gran Alternativa]]'' (1994) |nextevent=''[[Aniversario de Arena México#39. Aniversario de Arena México|39. Aniversario de Arena México]]'' }} In 1995 [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL) held a one-night single elimination Trios tournament dedicated to the memory of [[Salvador Lutteroth]], the founder of CMLL. The tournament filled the entire Friday night ''[[CMLL Super Viernes]]'' show, preceding the 1996 ''[[Homenaje a Salvador Lutteroth (1996)|Homenaje a Salvador Lutteroth]]'' show becoming the unofficial forerunner for the event that is now known as ''Homenaje a Dos Leyendas'' ("Homage to two Legends") that CMLL holds every spring.{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/emll/lutteroth.html#1995|title=Salvador Lutteroth Tournament 1995|date=March 24, 1995|accessdate=November 11, 2012|work=Pro Wrestling History}} The tournament was won by the team of [[Bestia Salvaje]], [[Emilio Charles Jr.]] and [[Sangre Chicana]], who received a trophy, but no other obvious awards for winning the tournament. ;Tournament participants *[[Apolo Dantés]], [[Atlantis (wrestler)|Atlantis]] and [[Rayo de Jalisco Jr.]] *[[Bestia Salvaje]], [[Emilio Charles Jr.]] and [[Sangre Chicana]] *Los Brazos ([[Brazo de Oro (wrestler)|Brazo de Oro]], [[Brazo de Plata]] and [[El Brazo]]) *[[Damian el Guerrero]], [[Guerrero del Futuro]] and [[Guerrero Maya]] *[[Dos Caras]], [[El Dandy]] and [[Héctor Garza]] *''La Ola Blanca'' ([[Dr. Wagner Jr.]], [[El Hijo del Gladiador]] and [[Gran Markus Jr.]] *[[Espectro Jr.]], [[Cadaver de Ultratumba]] and [[Astro Rey|Kahoz]] *[[Los Infernales]] ([[El Satánico]], [[Pirata Morgan]] and [[MS-1 (wrestler)|MS-1]]) ;Tournament brackets {{8TeamBracket | team-width=100em | RD1-team1=Damian el Guerrero, Guerrero del Futuro and Guerrero Maya | RD1-score1= | RD1-team2='''Los Salvaje, Emilio Charles Jr. and Sangre Chicana''' | RD1-score5=W | RD1-team6=''La Ola Blanca'' | RD1-score6= | RD1-team7=''Los Infernales'' | RD1-score7= | RD1-team8='''Dos Caras, El Dandy and Héctor Sangre Chicana''' | RD2-score3=W | RD2-team4=Dos Caras, El Dandy and Héctor Garza | RD2-score4= | RD3-team1=Los Brazos | RD3-score1= | RD3-team2='''Bestia Salvaje, Emilio Charles Jr. and Sangre Chicana''' | RD3-score2=W }} ==Salvador Lutteroth Tag Tournament== In 1999 [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL) held a one night, single elimination tournament on their annual ''[[Homenaje a Dos Leyendas: El Santo y Salvador Lutteroth (1999)|Homenaje a Dos Leyendas: El Santo y Salvador Lutteroth]]'' show, which took place on March 20, 1999. The tournament was dedicated to the memory of [[Salvador Lutteroth]], the founder of CMLL and followed both a singles tournament to honor Lutteroth the preceding year at the 1998 ''[[Homenaje a Salvador Lutteroth (1998)|Homenaje a Salvador Lutteroth]]'' show and a [[List of CMLL Tag Team Tournaments#Salvador Lutteroth Trios Tournament|Trios tournament]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/emll/lutteroth.html#1998|title=Salvador Lutteroth Tournament 1998|date=March 20, 1998|accessdate=October 20, 2012|publisher=Pro Wrestling History}}{{cite book|author=Madigan, Dan|title=Mondo Lucha a Go Go: the bizarre & honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling|publisher=HarperColins Publisher|year=2007|chapter=A family affair|pages=128–132|isbn=978-0-06-085583-3}} The tournament featured 8 teams in total, four teams of wrestlers whose careers peaked in the 1980s and early 1990s and four teams who were looking to make a name for themselves at the time. The last match saw the veterans [[Ringo Mendoza]] and [[Super Astro (wrestler)|Super Astro]] defeat the team of [[Mr. Niebla]] and [[Shocker (wrestler)|Shocker]] to win the tournament and the trophy. ;Veteran teams *[[Astro Rey|Kahoz]] and [[Scorpio Jr.]] *[[Ringo Mendoza]] and [[Super Astro (wrestler)|Super Astro]] *''Los Missioneros del Muerte'' ("The Missionaries of Death"; [[El Signo]] and [[Negro Navarro]]) *[[Fishman (wrestler)|Fisman]] and [[Villano III]] ;Younger generation *[[Último Guerrero]] and [[Violencia (wrestler)|Violencia]] *[[El Felino]] and [[Antonio Gómez Medina|Máscara Mágica]] *[[Olímpico]] and [[Tony Rivera]] *[[Mr. Niebla]] and [[Shocker (wrestler)|Shocker]]. {{8TeamBracket-NoSeeds | score-width=1em | team-width=100em | RD1=Quarter finals | RD2=Semi finals | RD3=Final | RD1-team1='''[[Último Guerrero]] and [[Violencia (wrestler)|Violencia]]''' | RD1-score1=W | RD1-team2=[[Astro Rey|Kahoz]] and [[Scorpio Jr.]] | RD1-score2= | RD1-team3='''[[Ringo Mendoza]] and [[Super Astro (wrestler)|Super Astro]]''' | RD1-score3=W | RD1-team4=[[El Felino]] and [[Antonio Gómez Medina|Máscara Mágica]] | RD1-score4= | RD1-team5='''[[El Signo]] and [[Negro Navarro]]''' | RD1-score5=W | RD1-team6=[[Olímpico]] and [[Tony Rivera]] | RD1-score6= | RD1-team7='''[[Mr. Niebla]] and [[Shocker (wrestler)|Shocker]]''' | RD1-score7=W | RD1-team8=[[Fishman (wrestler)|Fisman]] and [[Villano III]] | RD1-score8= | RD2-team1=Último Guerrero and Violencia | RD2-score1= | RD2-team2='''Ringo Mendoza and Super Astro''' | RD2-score2=W | RD2-team3=El Signo and Negro Navarro | RD2-score3= | RD2-team4='''Mr. Niebla and Shocker''' | RD2-score4=W | RD3-team1=Mr. Niebla and Shocker | RD3-score1= | RD3-team2='''Ringo Mendoza and Super Astro''' | RD3-score2=W }} ==Torneo Tanque Dantes== {{Infobox wrestling event |name=Torneo Tanque Dantsé |image= |caption= |promotion = [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] |date={{dts|2009|2|15}} to {{dts|2009|4|12}} |attendance= |venue=Arena Coliseo Guadalajara |city = [[Guadalajara, Jalisco]], [[Mexico]] |liveevent=Y |lastevent=''[[La Hora Cero]]'' |nextevent=''[[Homenaje a Dos Leyendas (2009)|Homenaje a Dos Leyendas]]'' (2009) }} In 2009 [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL) held a [[tag team]] tournament for wrestlers who work in CMLL's [[Guadalajara]], [[Jalisco]] Arena Coliseo and its associated wrestling training school. The tournament was named after Guadalajara native and wrestling pioneer ''Tanque'' (Tank) [[Alfonso Dantés]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fuegoenelring.com/articles_noticias_full.php?articles_id=59 |title=PRIMER TORNEO DE PAREJAS ALFONSO "TANQUE" DANTES |work=Fuego en el Ring |date=February 2, 2009 |language=Spanish |accessdate=November 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023061351/http://www.fuegoenelring.com/articles_noticias_full.php?articles_id=59 |archivedate=October 23, 2013 |df= }} The teams were paired up specifically for the tournament and did not work together on a regular basis prior to it. The teams all competed in a [[Round-robin tournament|round robin]] league format, earning points for victories (two) or draws (one).{{cite web|url=http://www.fuegoenelring.com/articles_noticias_full.php?pageNum_rs_articles_GDL=113&totalRows_rs_articles_GDL=572&articles_id=101 |title=A SUMAR SE HA DICHO PARA OBTENER |first=Ana |last=Gutierrez |date=February 2, 2009 |work=Fuego en el Ring |language=Spanish |accessdate=November 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023061516/http://www.fuegoenelring.com/articles_noticias_full.php?pageNum_rs_articles_GDL=113&totalRows_rs_articles_GDL=572&articles_id=101 |archivedate=October 23, 2013 |df= }} The tournament started on February 15, 2009 and ran until April 12 of that year, spanning five shows in Arena Coliseo. During the tournament wrestler Boomerang had to be replaced with [[Meteoro]] for one match and [[Mr. Trueno]] replaced [[Rey Trueno]] after just one match. The team of [[Titán (wrestler)|Palacio Negro]] and Samurai won the tournament with four victories, 1 loss and a total of 8 points.{{cite web|url=http://www.fuegoenelring.com/articles_noticias_full.php?pageNum_rs_articles_GDL=0&totalRows_rs_articles_GDL=461&pageNum_rs_articles=21&totalRows_rs_articles=87&articles_id=1371 |title=YA NO HAY VUELTA DE HOJA |date=August 11, 2010 |work=Fuego en el Ring |language=Spanish |accessdate=November 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023061518/http://www.fuegoenelring.com/articles_noticias_full.php?pageNum_rs_articles_GDL=0&totalRows_rs_articles_GDL=461&pageNum_rs_articles=21&totalRows_rs_articles=87&articles_id=1371 |archivedate=October 23, 2013 |df= }}
'''Teams and final standings''' {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- |Team |Win |Loss |Draw |Points |- |[[Palacio Negro]] and Samurai{{cite web|url=http://fuegoenelring.com/noticias/11.php?id=154 |title=EL TEXANO PONE LAS REGLAS |first=Ana |last=Gutierrez |work=Fuego en el Ring |language=Spanish |accessdate=November 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023062857/http://fuegoenelring.com/noticias/11.php?id=154 |archivedate=October 23, 2013 |df= }} |4 |1 |0 |8 |- |Boomerang/Meteoro and [[El Gallo (wrestler)|El Gallo]] |3 |1 |1 |7 |- |Leon Blanco and Thunder Boy |2 |2 |1 |5 |- |[[Ángel del Mal]] and Infierno |2 |3 |0 |4 |- |Acertijo and [[Rey Trueno]]/[[Mr. Trueno]] |2 |3 |0 |4 |- |Katana and Malefico |1 |4 |0 |2 |}
==Torneo Increibles de Parejas, Arena Puebla 2013== {{Infobox wrestling event |name=Torneo Increibles de Parejas |image= |caption= |promotion = [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] |date={{dts|2013|3|18}} to {{dts|2013|4|1}} |attendance= |venue=Arena Puebla |city = [[Puebla, Puebla]], Mexico |liveevent=Y |lastevent=''[[Homenaje a Dos Leyendas (2013)|Homenaje a Dos Leyendas]]'' (2013) |nextevent=[[Arena Coliseo 70th Anniversary Show]] }} Days after completing the 2013 ''[[CMLL Torneo Nacional de Parejas Increibles (2013)|Torneo Nacional de Parejas Increibles]]'' that concluded at the 2013 ''[[Homenaje a Dos Leyendas (2013)|Homenaje a Dos Leyendas]]'', CMLL held a similar tournament in Arena Puebla, in [[Puebla, Puebla]]. The tournament consisted of two qualifying blocks that took place on March 18 and 25, with a final on April 1, 2013. The tournament is based on the Lucha Libre ''[[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Parejas Increibles Match|Parejas Increibles]]'' match type where two wrestlers of opposite allegiance, portraying either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|villains]], referred to as "''Rudos''" in Lucha Libre wrestling terminology or [[Face (professional wrestling)|fan favorites]], or "''Technicos''".{{cite book|author=Madigan, Dan|title=Mondo Lucha Libre: the bizarre & honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling|publisher=HarperColins Publisher|year=2007|chapter=Okay... what is Lucha Libre?|pages=29–40|isbn=978-0-06-085583-3}} At times some of the team members were part of a pre-existing [[script (recorded media)|scripted]] [[Feud (professional wrestling)|feuds]] or [[narrative thread|storylines]] with each other. The tournament was won by [[Atlantis (wrestler)|Atlantis]] and [[Volador Jr.]] as they defeated [[Shocker (wrestler)|Shocker]] and [[Rey Bucanero]] in the finals after the team failed to get along. ;Tournament Participants ;Key {| class="wikitable" |- !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Symbol !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Meaning |- |{{small|(T)}} |This wrestler is a ''[[Face (professional wrestling)|Tecnico]]'' |- |{{small|(R)}} |This wrestler is a ''[[Heel (professional wrestling)|Rudo]]'' |} ;Block A (March 18, 2013) *[[Ángel de Oro]] {{small|(T)}} and [[Rey Escorpión]] {{small|(R)}} *[[Atlantis (wrestler)|Atlantis]] {{small|(T)}} and [[Volador Jr.]] {{small|(R)}} *[[Blue Panther]] {{small|(T)}} and [[Averno (wrestler)|Averno]] {{small|(R)}} *[[Máscara Dorada]] {{small|(T)}} and page.title: List of entertainment events at Perth Arena

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=November 2016}} [[RAC Arena (Perth)|RAC Arena]] is the busiest venue in [[Western Australia]], with many local, regional and international artists having staged their performance at the arena. All events are arranged in an chronological order below while non-concert entertainment events are also included.

! width=100| Artists

opens doors for local acts |first=Kristy |last=Symonds |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/perth-arena-opens-doors-for-local-acts/story-e6frf7jo-1226509764337 |newspaper=[[Herald Sun]] |date=3 {{Dynamic list}}
This is a '''list of plays and musicals about the [[American Revolution]]'''.
* ''[[1776 (musical)|1776]]''  – 1969 Broadway musical; Composed by [[Sherman Edwards]] * ''[[Ben Franklin in Paris]]''  – 1964 musical by Sidney Michaels * ''[[A New World: A Life of Thomas Paine]]''  – 2009 stage play by [[Trevor Griffiths]] * ''[[Jefferson's Garden]]''  – 2015 stage play by [[Timberlake Wertenbaker]] * ''[[Hamilton (musical)|Hamilton]]''  – 2015 musical by [[Lin-Manuel Miranda]] * ''[[The Ruckus at Machias]]''  – 1976 play by Richard Sewell * ''[[Valley Forge]]''  -1934 play by [[Maxwell Anderson]]
